body: History buffs and first-time visitors had questions this week. Send me your own dining queries via dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton. Q. My partner and I are students of history, particularly New York City during the World War II years. I'm a native New Yorker, so I actually got to eat at the last Automat in the city on 42nd Street
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; In Search of History on a Plate

body: THE best of the casual restaurants reviewed this year proved that delicious doesn't have to mean expensive. AYADA This is a serious Thai restaurant that makes no concessions to Western palates. The menu is encyclopedic; the waitresses are patient. Put yourself in the gentle but firm hands of the chef and owner, Duangjai Thammasat (known as Kitty),
title: Breaking the Mold, Not the Bank

body: In technology circles, people talk about the merits of eating your own dog food -- making sure your company is actually using the same products or services it is selling. Etsy, an independent online marketplace for handmade products and vintage goods, is getting its fair share of dog food. Most everything in the company's sprawling offices in the
title: Online Bazaar Builds on Its Base With Sense of Community

body: SALUTING the new year huddled around the hearth with family and friends -- bedecked in sequins and plastic ''2011'' spectacles, spilling warm Champagne on the sofa -- is good, old-fashioned fun. But wouldn't you rather spend the night with Patti Smith? Whether you're bidding 2010 a hearty, don't-let-the-door-hit-you-on-the-way-out farewell or
title: Beyond Popping Corks, The Sounds of the New Year

body: A reader wanted to know whether she could take her young children to the Peter Luger steakhouse in Brooklyn. You'll see how I answered, and what other readers had to say about that, below. Also: Where to take parents who resemble George Costanza's, from ''Seinfeld.'' Now, to the questions! Q. My brother-in-law, his pregnant wife and their three
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; This Shrine to Steak Deserves a Little More Respect

body: Best appreciated drunk or otherwise impaired, ''Satan Hates You'' is the kind of horror movie that appears to have been shot in someone's basement using a box of old Halloween costumes. title: Film in Review | Satan Hates You

body: The Beijing-born, New York-based filmmaker Miao Wang follows three cabbies around her old hometown in the picturesque documentary ''Beijing Taxi,'' filmed over several years leading up to the 2008 Beijing Olympics. The cabbies have interesting and poignant things to say about being left behind in China's rush to modernize, and Ms. Wang; her
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'BEIJING TAXI'; Bystanders To China's Transition

body: The 19th annual Double Dutch Holiday Classic is a competition that goes beyond anything you saw as a kid at your neighborhood playground. On Sunday students from around the world compete for spots on national and international double dutch teams, using, well, themselves and jump ropes, along with music, dance and gymnastics. The festivities begin
title: Weekend Miser

body: Beginning with accidentally sprayed Russian mucus and ending with deliberately deployed American urine, the plot of ''Mars'' owes at least as much to bodily fluids as it does to science fiction. Low key, low budget and low energy, this animated space odyssey from the writer and director Geoff Marslett accompanies three mismatched astronauts to the
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'MARS'; An Animated Space Odyssey

body: RAYMAN BOOZER is a survivor, a member of that hardy (dare one say quixotic?) tribe known as independent retailers. Sixteen years ago, Mr. Boozer, an Indiana-born interior designer, opened Apartment 48 on West 17th Street. He had worked at Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue and Conran's and was eager to create his own retail magic. He laid out his
title: Small Shops, Big Wonders

body: IN the end, it was the pool ball -- faded, impaled on a rod, stuck to a small platform -- that almost got me. A few of them ($28 each) were clustered on a table near the back of Modern Anthology, like immobilized, castrated gearshifts from a 1950s rebel flick. A paperweight? An ad-hoc weapon? More like a trigger, the worn-down colors redolent of
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER | MODERN ANTHOLOGY; Manly, or Close

body: Greg Gunn and Larry Berger met as Rhodes scholars at Oxford University and, after stints teaching computer skills and mathematics to children in Harlem and Stamford, Conn., they came upon an idea: create a business that would put technology in the hands of teachers and into classrooms. Mr. Gunn, 40, and Mr. Berger, 42, founded Wireless Generation
title: News Corp., After Hiring Klein, Buys Technology Partner in a City Schools Project

body: Come and meet these dancing feet. If you dare. No little girl who sees the Kneehigh Theater's adaptation of ''The Red Shoes'' (not that any little girl should) will leave with sweet dreams of becoming a ballet dancer. This imaginative, so-ugly-it's-beautiful production, at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn through Dec. 12, is more likely to inspire
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'THE RED SHOES'; Dance-Struck Little Girls: Run! Run in Horror!

body: WHOEVER said New York night life is dead hasn't been out recently. Despite the economic gloom, or maybe because of it, a crush of late-night parties, luscious lounges and chest-thumping clubs are opening across the city. The meatpacking district is a tangle of new velvet ropes. D.J.'s are trekking to the nether reaches of Bushwick. The Lower East
title: The New Club Kids

body: St. Ann's Warehouse, the Dumbo-based theater best known for presenting work from the Wooster Group and other downtown favorites, has been conditionally designated by the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation to become the primary tenant of the Tobacco Warehouse, located across the street from the theater's current home. Last year St. Ann's began a
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; A Possible New Home For St. Ann's Warehouse

body: There must be chief executives and millionaire athletes in Austin, Tex., whom Bob Ray could make documentaries about, but he doesn't seem to be interested. title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'TOTAL BADASS' AND 'HELL ON WHEELS'; Sport and Grim Reality

body: ''Modern art is a con. I am the world's greatest con artist.'' ''Fame is love; I need love.'' ''Da Vinci and Michelangelo: I can see the dandruff on their heads as I look from above down on them.'' Those are some of the sassier remarks by Mark Kostabi in ''Con Artist,'' Michael Sladek's entertaining documentary portrait of one of the art world's
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'CON ARTIST'; The (Un)Making of an Art World Satirist

Well, save your cash, because the miser is offering a weekend of free readings, talks and ''Friday Night Lights.'' On Saturday, Staten Island OutLOUD, a community dialogue and performance
title: Weekend Miser

body: After New York State passed a law this summer extending residential rights to people living in illegal lofts in much of the city, the seven tenants of 360 Jefferson Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, acted fast. Theirs was not a pretty building: two and a half stories of dung-colored bricks punctuated by windows encased in rusting metal mesh, on a
title: Seeking a New Law's Protection, Loft Tenants Instead Find Grief

body: YOU'RE never too old to dress up for Halloween, but after about 13, if you turn up at an unsuspecting someone's door looking for candy, you could end up in the back of a squad car. For those with an aching sweet tooth, there are still candy stores in the city, from the 500-square-foot Sweet Life on the edge of Chinatown to the 15,000-square-foot
title: Ye Olde Craving Calling?

body: There they fester on the floor of that empty swimming pool, four men in Speedos, past their prime. Once they were legion, but they have dwindled to these lucky (or unlucky) few, and their days pass in a blur of sun-bleached sameness. Yet after 20 years, they remain gripped by the same fever of anticipation. They are waiting -- hold for it -- for
title: THEATER REVIEW; In Far Over Their Heads: Life at the Pool's Bottom

body: Opening BROOKLYN WINERY A second New York City winery has opened. As at City Winery in Manhattan, the owners here, Brian Leventhal and John Stires, and their winemaker, Conor McCormack (above), bring grapes in from New York State and California to crush and make wines, expected to start being ready in about a year. Individuals and groups can buy
title: Off the Menu

body: FROM the window of his waterfront office in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, Sufjan Stevens can see traffic creeping along Manhattan's eastern edge, just across the river. He can see the party boats and barges float by, joined occasionally by groups of kayakers. And he can see the workers at the Con Edison power plant across from his building. It
title: Mr. Strummy-Strum Tries a Synth Sound

body: Theater Jason Zinoman The conceit of ENDA WALSH'S new play, ''Penelope'' -- which like several of his bittersweet, densely poetic plays (''The Walworth Farce,'' ''The New Electric Ballroom''), was a hit at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe -- adopts the trusty strategy: Take a famous story, then reimagine it from the perspective of a minor
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | OCT. 17--OCT. 23

body: ''Red White & Blue,'' the latest feature from the British director Simon Rumley, builds a triptych of character studies into an engrossing -- and profoundly distressing -- tale of random connection and specific revenge. Erica (Amanda Fuller), a wistful nymphomaniac, trawls the bars and clubs of Austin, Tex., wearing tiny shorts and gigantic
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'RED WHITE & BLUE'; Loose Connections That Lead to Horror

body: A strange hybrid of personal journey, half-baked documentary and cleverly executed tease, ''S&Man'' (pronounced ''Sandman'') gets up close and personal with three of the more extreme makers of underground horror and fetish films. Only two appear as themselves, but you'll have to wait for the end credits to learn which; suffice to say that the actor
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'S&MAN'; Shots From the Underground

body: Tap-dancing bears, kung fu juggling, clown bands, aerialists, sword swallowers, cowboys and a cougar contortionist -- these are just a few of the acts that the Bindlestiff Family Cirkus has brought to the stage at Galapagos Art Space in Brooklyn over the last few years. Once a month Keith Nelson, a founder of the Cirkus and host of Bindlestiff
title: Weekend Miser

body: ALEXIS BITTAR'S colorful bracelets for fall are hand carved and painted in his studio in Dumbo, Brooklyn, which has a production staff of about 200. Items include a small hinge bracelet made of Lucite in a color named ruby dust (top of stack, $265); a skinny tapered bangle in purple (middle, $55), and a hinge bracelet in gunmetal (bottom, $595).
title: BROWSING; Wrist Management

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Morgan Library & Museum Tuesday at 6:30 p.m., a discussion about Mark Twain's legacy by writers who are also avid readers of his work: the humorist Fran Lebowitz, the novelist Toni Morrison and the New York Times columnist Frank Rich; $30, $25 for members. The discussion is in conjunction with the exhibition ''Mark
title: Spare Times

body: Three short films that probably need ''don't try this at home'' warnings constitute a nutty, nicely conceived bill at the ReRun Gastropub Theater in Brooklyn. ''Liquor and Drugs'' is the program's subtitle, and liquor and drugs are used and abused rather a lot in the films, which don't exactly issue ringing endorsements of moderation. The best of
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'SHORTS REMIX'; Brief Films About Staying Off the Wagon

body: Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. - Batsheva Dance Company (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) Ohad Naharin, who is fond of experimenting with choreographic structures, is presenting two versions of his evening-long ''Project 5.'' The all-male cast opens on Friday night and performs again on Saturday
title: The Listings

body: Some grown-ups may need a refresher course in sharing, but the hosts of this week's events deserve a gold star for inviting misers to take in their free lectures, music and games. CreativeMornings is a free lecture series for early-bird ''creative types,'' according to the organizer, Tina Roth Eisenberg, a k a ''swissmiss,'' a designer and blogger.
title: Weekend Miser

body: POP-UPS The MADLY is selling its one-of-a-kind men's bags, crafted from leather and organic textiles, at 350 Bowery (Great Jones Street); (917) 881-3066, themadly .com. The Fitzgerald, an overnight carry-on is $495; the Kilgore, a messenger bag inspired by a traditional fisherman bag, is $395. A gallery of photographs taken in Peru by one of the
title: Scouting Report

body: The Rorschach allure of the dark, leafy shapes have you admiring the crisp kale chips before you nibble. Thin and glazed with various seasonings, they not only are snack worthy and packed with nutrients, but they also can be used for dipping or as a salad topping or a garnish for all sorts of dishes, like baked fish or even soups. Amy Hamberry and
title: FOOD STUFF; Nutritious Chips: Not an Oxymoron

body: ON a recent drizzly afternoon in Bushwick, Brooklyn, members of the Bushwick Food Cooperative gathered beneath a tent in a ramshackle backyard to claim their share of the weekly harvest. They picked through crates of cilantro and rosemary from a rooftop farm in Long Island City, Queens, and examined pastured eggs from an Amish farm cooperative in
title: A Commune Grows in Brooklyn

title: A Commune Grows in Brooklyn

One has an all-woman cast, which opens the engagement on Tuesday. Then the men take over in the same

body: The sustaining joke of ''The Happy Poet,'' an indie comedy written and directed by Paul Gordon, is that the poet wants to be happy but doesn't really know how to go about it. It's a pretty good joke, and Mr. Gordon tells it with enough discipline and invention to make a significant portion of the film funny in interesting, subversive ways. He is
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'THE HAPPY POET'; A Poet Who Wants a Change

body: Beware all you New Yorkers and tourists who have yet to kick the habit. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has already banned smoking in restaurants and bars, wants to prohibit it in much of the great outdoors: parks, beaches and even pedestrian malls and plazas like those around Times Square, on Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn and Broadway on the Upper
title: Mayor's Next Targets for a Smoking Ban: Parks and Beaches

body: Jeremy Lamberton's sometimes amusing documentary ''Biker Fox'' is many things: a portrait of an idealist preaching a gospel of bicycling, loving nature and helping one's fellow man; a study of anger management, or the lack thereof; an examination of someone unaware of his own acute loneliness. The title subject is Frank P. DeLarzelere (also a
title: MOVIE REVIEW; Biker Fox

body: A boy loses his rodent and finds a girl in ''Etienne!,'' a sunny-sweet fable about healing wounds with the balm of the open road. Richard (Richard Vallejos) lives a miniature life. By day he performs small repairs in a boutique hotel in San Francisco; by night he inhabits a tiny room with Etienne, his beloved dwarf hamster. Surrounded by elaborate,
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'ETIENNE!'; Rodent Road Trip and Human Bonds

body: WEEKEND brunch is a luxurious, late-morning salve, a counterpoint to no-nonsense weekday breakfasts devoured on subway platforms or half-chewed while reading e-mail. Hangovers are tended to with syrup-soaked pancakes and jam-slathered toast, as diners drift gently into a not-unpleasant carbohydrate haze. (It helps that brunch is also one of the
title: Have Your Brunch And Listen To It, Too

body: A zombie movie like no other, ''Make-Out With Violence'' uses an undead crush to explore one of our most wrenching transitions: that long, hot summer between high school and adulthood. The title is something of a misnomer. Featuring precious little making out and even less violence, this downright dreamy fable about the difficulty of letting go --
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'MAKE-OUT WITH VIOLENCE'; A Teenage Zombie Crush

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Cocktails@Cooper-Hewitt Each Friday this month the terrace and garden will be open, rain or shine, from 6 to 9 p.m.; this Friday features music by the jazz ensemble the Ed Fuqua Group, refreshments and entry to the exhibitions. Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, Arthur Ross Terrace and Garden, 2 East 91st Street,
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Midway through ''Modern Love Is Automatic,'' a scruffy film by Zach Clark about a nurse who decides to log time as a dominatrix, someone asks the nurse, Lorraine (Melodie Sisk), why she wants to try this new career. She has no answer. And at that moment, you may think that Mr. Clark, too, has no answer to the question of why he wanted to make a
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'MODERN LOVE IS AUTOMATIC'; A Nurse as Dominatrix

body: ALEXANDRA HARCHAREK will never forget the first time she was anointed the ''mayor'' of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge in Philadelphia. It was an overcast Wednesday in April and she was driving to the city on her last day of an internship. Never mind that she had to drive 15 minutes out of her way from her apartment in Sewell, N.J., to her desk at the
title: Who Elected Me Mayor? I Did

body: India Day Parade and Festival (Sunday) Lower Madison Avenue will be teeming with the sights, sounds and tastes of India on Sunday at the 30th India Day Parade and Festival, commemorating the 64th anniversary of India Independence Day. The fun begins at 11 a.m. with a street fair from 23rd to 26th Streets. The first of more than 300 performers from
title: Spare Times: Around Town

body: Part documentary, part performance film, ''Trust Us, This Is All Made Up'' explores the magic and mystery of long-form improv with nothing but two men, three chairs, eight cameras and an expectant audience. But these are no ordinary men. As the highly regarded comedy duo known as T J and Dave, T J Jagodowski and David Pasquesi improvise hourlong
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'TRUST US, THIS IS ALL MADE UP'; Creating Plays On the Go, Right Onstage

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Alice Austen House Outdoor events: On Friday, ''Rock the House,'' music with a D.J. beginning at 7 p.m. and live bands from 8 to 10 p.m. On Saturday at 6:30 p.m., a dance program built around the themes of nature and the life of Isadora Duncan, presented by the Isadora Duncan Dance Company, the youth dance ensemble
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Watching ''The Parking Lot Movie,'' a quirky documentary about, yes, a parking lot, is probably not unlike working at such a lot: there are long stretches when not much happens, but every once in a while there's a burst of activity that is kind of enthralling. The filmmaker, Meghan Eckman, focused on a scruffy patch of pavement called the Corner
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'THE PARKING LOT MOVIE'; Imperfect Attendants

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Jewish Museum Thursday at 6:30 p.m., a screening of ''The Goldbergs'' (1950) by Walter Hart, based on the radio and television series ''The Goldbergs,'' which starred Gertrude Berg and featured the daily lives of a Jewish family in the Bronx; $15, $12 for students and 65+, $10 for members (includes admission to museum
title: Spare Times

body: Sunny is a former high school honors student who dropped out of college a year or so ago to tend her father, who's dying of cancer. Now she's working at a bowling alley in Pensacola, Fla.; dating her well-meaning but unambitious boyfriend, Neal; hanging with her best friend, Amy, who is rearing a baby after a shotgun marriage to the child's dim
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'THE NEW YEAR'; Serious Adulthood Waiting to Happen

body: AQUAVIT 65 East 55th Street (Madison Avenue), Midtown; (212) 307-7311; aquavit.org. In this corporate Sweden, Marcus Jernmark is moving forward with a menu that is more traditionally Scandinavian than the one put forth by his predecessor, the celebrity chef Marcus Samuelsson. There are meatballs in the bistro up front, and heady gravlax, while in
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

author: Rachel Birnbaum lives in the Dumbo neighborhood of Brooklyn and works as a copywriter at a Midtown ad agency.
body: A couple of months ago, I downloaded CabSense, a new iPhone app that identifies the best corners in New York City to catch a cab. Now I just need an app that helps me avoid being intercepted by transit bandits. I'm referring to those catlike creatures who will snatch your rightfully earned taxi out from under your outstretched arm. One moment,
title: CITY ROOM; Complaint Box | Taxi Snatchers; That's My . . . That Was My Cab!

body: Ron Hogan (Anthony Baker), an angry young man in Chicago, appears to be angry about the usual things -- his boring office job, the frustrations of dating, the shallowness of the people around him, the lack of transcendence in his life. It's hard to tell or to care, though, because the character is dull and closed off, and the film he dominates,
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'AUDREY THE TRAINWRECK'; A Slice of Midwestern Mumblecore

body: Austin, Tex., has the Alamo Drafthouse. San Francisco has Foreign Cinema. Portland, Ore., has McMenamins. And Brooklyn has -- well, Brooklyn has many places where you can bring a blanket and a picnic basket and watch a film in a park or on a rooftop, but few indoor options for dinner-and-a-movie year-round. That will change on Friday, with the
title: Movie on the Screen, Dinner on the Plate, Hubcaps at the Bar

body: With our views blocked by concrete and metal, it is easy to forget that New York is surrounded by water. That's why on Saturday, the third annual City of Water Day Festival will let the masses ferry, paddle, row, canoe and kayak their way to the city's waterfronts for a full day of free activities sponsored by the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance
title: WEEKEND MISER; City of Water Day Festival

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Louis Armstrong House Museum Saturday at 1 p.m., a free outdoor performance of Dixieland, early jazz and spirituals by the group the Recessionals. The museum is open Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Louis Armstrong House Museum, 34-56 107th Street, Corona, Queens ,
title: Spare Times

body: Cory Vaughn, a slugging outfielder and son of the former major league All-Star Greg Vaughn, is the new star of the Brooklyn Cyclones. Here is a little scouting report on him: He slides into base on his left hip, and when patrolling right field, in the shadow of the famous Coney Island Parachute Jump, he is loath to dive on his right side. These are
title: CITY ROOM; Sweat; Bats Right, Slides Left

body: Wild West kitsch will take over Christie's plush quarters at Rockefeller Center at noon on Friday. title: ANTIQUES; Meeting Again, At the Auction House

body: New York can make a hungry miser's dreams come true. NYC Restaurant Week begins on Monday, and that means meals at hundreds of the best restaurants are available for a steal. The fixed prices can buy a fancy lunch at Blue Fin for $24.07 and an elegant dinner at the Red Cat for $35. Or just stop by the Restaurant Week Truck, which will be serving
title: WEEKEND MISER

body: BALABOOSTA 214 Mulberry Street (Spring Street), NoLIta, (212) 966-7366. Einat Admony's charming and casual Middle Eastern trattoria with Israeli roots is near the top end of Little Italy, a full-grown offshoot of her West Village falafel joint, Taim. It has the sound level of a good family gathering, not so loud that you need to shout, and not so
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

author: Nathan Ward is the author of ''Dark Harbor: The War for the New York Waterfront.''
body: THIS summer, with the debut of the Brooklyn Bridge Park, as well as the expansion of Manhattan's Hudson River Park and Governors Island, New Yorkers have celebrated the reclamation of the waterfront. But the effort, laudable though it is, obscures a not-so-insignificant historical misunderstanding: we are in fact claiming the waterfront, not
title: OP-ED CONTRIBUTOR; Take Me to the River. Finally.

body: Over the last decade, a growing stream of the young, the stylish and the family-oriented have been drawn to Brooklyn by its parks, waterfront, cultural life and relatively affordable real estate and acres of graceful brownstones. But when it comes time for those newcomers to have their babies, they are tied as if by an umbilical cord to Manhattan.
title: A Manhattan Birth Certificate, But an Address in Brooklyn

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Governors Island Special and weekly summer programs: ''Free Bike Fridays,'' 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., with free hourlong use of rental bicycles through Oct. 8. title: Spare Times

title: SPARE TIMES

body: BRAGGING rights for homeowners are fleeting, hard to hold as a fistful of fog. You think your home is special because your backsplash is covered in tile imported from Mexico? There are those who think nothing of dispatching their architects and builders to the ends of the earth to personally scope out far more exotic goods -- to the Middle East for
title: The Trophy Hunters

body: IF your renovation budget does not permit you to send your contractor or architect to the Far East for exotic woods or stone, don't despair -- there are places closer to home that they go themselves. For homegrown exotic woods, Stephen Fanuka, a New York City contractor, recommends Timeless Timber, which sells North American wood that sank to the
title: Finding Exotic Materials Closer to Home

body: HUITLACOCHE, a corn fungus that's a delicacy in Mexican cuisine, doesn't always fulfill its funky potential. Too often it's bland and mushy, a bit of name-dropping on the menu that doesn't do much on the plate. Not so at Hecho en Dumbo, which recently moved to the Bowery after three years in Brooklyn. Here the quesadillas de huitlacoche ($10) have
title: $25 AND UNDER; A Mexican Import, by Way of Brooklyn

body: Cooking in Verse Readings of poems about food will be given to celebrate the 10th issue of Alimentum, a literary food journal, on June 19 from 5 to 7 p.m. at Smalls Jazz Club, 183 West 10th Street (Seventh Avenue South). title: Calendar

body: CENTENNIAL BEE-DAY PARTY In Kafka's ''Metamorphosis'' Gregor Samsa awakens to discover that he has become an enormous cockroach. While that may be among the most unwelcome transformations on record, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will offer one on Saturday that's shorter, sweeter and sunnier: children changing themselves into bees. The process is part
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Openings WOK NEW YORK Formerly Walk to Wok. title: Off the Menu

body: IN addition to every sports bar in town, many restaurants will show World Cup matches from South Africa, offering special food deals and drinks, often themed to the nationalities of the competing teams on particular days. Some matches will be shown live, starting at 6:30 a.m. The tournament begins on June 11 and continues through July 11. The
title: DINING CALENDAR; World Cup Dining

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: From water's edge you can cross the Hudson River -- or the East River, as you prefer -- in less time than it often takes to wait for the subway. Even at the height of rush hour, you'll get a seat, quite likely one near a window. From out on the water, the city you think you know will seem taller, more glamorous, more cinematic. You may pass under a
title: CITY CRITIC; What New York Needs: More Water Taxis

body: WHEN Jen Rosenbaum told her colleagues that she was determined to find an apartment for just $1,200 to $1,500 a month, they laughed. Clearly, she was on a fool's errand. ''My co-workers said it is not going to happen, you are insane,'' she said. But Miss Rosenbaum was certain she could easily find a great cheap apartment. After all, she had heard
title: THE HUNT; An Optimist Goes After the Near-Impossible

body: VICTOR HSU, above, who calls himself the chief propagandist for the sneaker brand Jump, is getting the word out with a pop-up store in the Dumbo neighborhood of Brooklyn; it is called Jumbo, an acronym for Jump Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass. Jumbo will have its opening party Thursday from 6:30 to 10 p.m. Jump offerings run from flashy
title: BROWSING; Pop Up, Jump Under

title: THE WEEK AHEAD | MAY 30--JUNE 5

title: At Navy Yard, Preservation Arrives Late

title: Spare Times

body: IF you're fortunate enough to have outdoor space, lighting it properly ''can make a big difference,'' said the landscape architect Steven Tupu. ''Even a small amount of lighting,'' he said, can ''change an outdoor space in a really dynamic way.'' Especially when it comes to the ''small, forgotten spaces like terraces, back alleys and interior
title: SHOPPING WITH STEVEN TUPU; Outdoor Light Show

body: The warm-weather sidewalks around Bryant Park are usually as packed as the stateroom scene in the Marx Brothers' ''Night at the Opera.'' But beginning on Monday, if pedestrians plowing through raise their weary heads, they will encounter a vision of truly stunning Midtown Manhattan density in the air above them. Seven women in identical bright
title: Pounding the Pavement From Up on a Pedestal

body: LUCKYRICE Most entrants into America's ever-shifting cuisine arrive via the high road (like sushi, a byproduct of Japanese-American corporate ties) or the low road (chitterlings, a soul food with origins in the scraps given to slaves). And some cuisines arrive and remain in the middle, becoming items that people unthinkingly incorporate into a
title: Spare Times

body: A year ago, Tough Mudder was a semifinalist in the Harvard Business School's annual Business Plan Contest. title: Playing With Fire, Barbed Wire and Beer

body: ANY renovation, from a minor change to a major overhaul, offers the opportunity to reduce energy and water use and improve the comfort of a home. That's a message Tony Daniels, an advisory board member for the nonprofit group GreenHomeNYC, is happy to promote. Mr. Daniels, a New York architect, became a ''LEED-accredited professional'' -- a term
title: SHOPPING WITH TONY DANIELS; Save Your Energy

body: Greg Woodworth and Kelly Coughlin were selling cookies in Geneva, N.Y. Peter Martin was a farmer processing butternut squash for supermarkets, with seeds to spare. Now, the three are producing Stony Brook butternut squash oil -- golden and nutty, tasting slightly of sesame. They also have a delicata squash oil the color of raspberries, with a more
title: FOOD STUFF; With Seed Money, Group Strikes Oil

body: Not until about 9:45 a.m. on Monday, the morning of its reopening, did Gorilla Coffee in Brooklyn begin to look a little like its old self. A few patrons lined up at the cash register, waiting for lattes and Balthazar pastries; a smattering of others sat at shiny red tables, tapping away at laptops. For Gorilla, which has become a Park Slope
title: Brewing Coffee Again in Brooklyn After a Barista Walkout

body: A mash-up, a conceptual exercise, an amateur talent show, a pop critique, piano-bar karaoke and a meditation on mortality: that's ''End of the Road,'' the production of the Young@Heart Chorus by No Theater, at St. Ann's Warehouse through May 1. Young@Heart, whose members are in their 70s and up, was founded in 1982 at a housing development for the
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Pop Songs Exhibiting A Measure Of Mortality

body: THERE are two Shien Lees: the schoolgirl, demure in a checkered frock and cardigan; and the siren, faintly dissolute in a lace-edged scarlet frock. Ms. Lee, a recent graduate of Columbia University, is fresh-scrubbed by day, pursuing a range of cultural interests that include the study of 1920s German art and 18th-century opera. By night, she is an
title: Priestess of the Night

body: The real estate firm Two Trees Management is expanding the Dumbo Arts Festival in Brooklyn, adding a greater diversity of programming to a mix that already includes visual art and performances. The festival will now be organized by a variety of arts professionals, rather than solely by the Dumbo Arts Center, which founded it. The festival, entering
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Festival Grows

title: TAKING QUESTIONS FUN FOR CHILDREN; Family Getaways Off the Beaten Paths

body: When Amos Vogel and his wife, Marcia, formed the avant-garde film society Cinema 16 more than 60 years ago, they created an avenue that would introduce American moviegoers to a new sensibility evident in the works of Roman Polanski, John Cassavetes, Alain Resnais and other filmmakers. title: Spare Times: Cinema 16

body: The program handed out to those arriving for ''Body Maps'' at Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo, Brooklyn, on Friday night succinctly stated the event's premise, ''an evening of music and film featuring artists who have crossed oceans.'' That what transpired hardly seemed so clear cut was to be expected given the event's architects: the composer Paola
title: MUSIC REVIEW | 'BODY MAPS'; Boundaries Shift in Mixing and Matching of Artists and Images

body: The mayor's office was in such a rush to showcase the completion of the first phase of its new Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn that it opened it too soon. title: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW | BROOKLYN BRIDGE PARK; The Greening Of the Waterfront

title: THE POUR; Good Wines And No Attitude. Yes, It's True.

body: It was a soggy morning, but no rain would fall on the parade, the politicians insisted. On this, the long-anticipated official opening day of Brooklyn Bridge Park, no spirit would be dampened -- drizzle or no, they said, it was a sunny, sunny day for New York and the world, a celebration of Brooklyn's present, a harbinger of its future. ''I'm not
title: BIG CITY; A Peaceful Refuge in Brooklyn, and All the Noise It Took to Build It

body: AFTER Tina Chang puts her 7-month-old son, Roman, to bed, she pads, barefoot, about three feet over to her office, where a desk cohabits with the changing table. title: A Poet Who Doesn't Do Lofty

body: IT'S not easy being a Mexican restaurant in the United States. Some customers are outraged if the menu doesn't have burritos; others, if it does. Some see authenticity when chips and salsa aren't on the table; others see a rip-off. ''Everybody here thinks they know what Mexican food is,'' said Nicholas Cox, the chef at La Esquina in NoLIta.
title: The Soul of Mexico (Hold the Chips)

title: THEATER REVIEW | 'A LIFE IN THREE ACTS'; Of Youth, Frocks and Politics: A Not-So-Ordinary Life

title: LIVING IN | VINEGAR HILL, BROOKLYN; The Little Town That Prices (Almost) Forgot

body: Around 9 on Wednesday night Stew and his band had just finished ''Leave/Believe,'' a terse, mopey number that stops cold in the middle of a sad feeling and never resumes, or redeems. Wordlessly the group left the stage. The St. Ann's Warehouse house lights didn't brighten. The audience waited expectantly for a couple of minutes, and got nothing.
title: MUSIC REVIEW | 'MAKING IT'; Soundtrack of Their End: Romance Curdles Onstage

body: IT was Valentine's Day at the House of Yes, an old ice warehouse turned event space in Bushwick, Brooklyn: The three-story ''skybox'' was swathed in red satin and velvet, and red aerialists' silks hung from the circus truss that spanned the ceiling. title: Decorating the Night

body: Hunched over their computers on a recent afternoon, two brothers were sketching plans to build a green roof for an elementary school in Brooklyn. title: At Shared Offices, How Green Is My Work Space

title: BIG DEAL; One Costly Condo

title: The Listings

body: Tuli Kupferberg, a leader of the Fugs, was 41 when that Lower East Side band started in 1964. He had a Depression-era New York catarrhal croak, and cheerful paranoia. He wasn't cute, and was a chanter, not a singer. Two other band members, Ed Sanders and Ken Weaver, carried the melodies. Mr. Kupferberg was both ultracynical and ultraidealistic.
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Generations of Admirers Play Their Respects
